results.title: The Golden dragons
results.creator_credit: Dean Lawry, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description: Bendigo - Bendigo’s annual Easter parade has featured the Dragon and Lion dancers from the Bendigo Chinese Association for over 100 years. This mini documentary explores how this historical tradition has helped shape the identities of the dancers and features interviews combined with footage of their colourful and exciting dance held at dusk at the Dragons’ spiritual home - Bendigo’s Golden Dragon Museum of Australia
results.description: Bendigo - Bendigo’s annual Easter parade has featured the Dragon and Lion dancers from the Bendigo Chinese Association for over 100 years. results.title: Tomatoes for processing
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Rod Kefford, Ann Millard and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
Film begins with instructions on how to garner and prepare tomato seeds for planting, before focusing on the seed germination process and how to cultivate a good crop of seedlings.

The seedlings are then uprooted and planted in larger fields. Manual and semi-automatic seedling planting techniques are shown using different types of machinery.

When fully grown the tomatoes are picked and packed into wooden crates. Film details the correct picking and packing process.

Finally, the tomatoes are taken to a factory, where they are pulped and made into tomato sauce.

Good colour/shoits throughout.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.brief_description:
‘Harry She’llberight’ is a lazy farmer, stuck in the ‘old ways’ of chemical spraying. He provides a ‘worst case scenario’ of chemical spray use. A representative of the Vistorian Department of Agriculture assists Harry in modern spraying techniques, equipment and safety. Along the way we are introduced to different spray epuipment and how it operates away from Harry’s farm.

Harry is a comical character and he eventually gets his act together as the film progresses.

Opening contains nice shots of people picking lettuce and scens inside of a vegetable market.

Good cartoon-like illustrations about chemical spraying safety.

results.title: Roar culture
results.brief_description:
‘Roar culture’ is a successful six month community arts project that was documented on video. The project brought together schools, community groups, artists, people from culturally diverse backgrounds and local government, including over 80 students, 10 storytellers, and 14 artists/mentors. ‘Roar culture’ explores issues of identity concerning ethnic, religious & sexual discrimination, cultural diversity and tolerance.
In doing so, it was critical to the process that there was a space for understanding and insight: a space where the many faces and voices which contribute to Bendigo’s historical and contemporary image and identity, were paid attention.
Stage one: the project’s starting point was the narrative or story. Stories from 10 multicultural & indigenous individuals whose memories ranged from the 1930s through to today, from places and countries which hauntingly navigated us to Bendigo. Each told a different story about living in regional Victoria however the threads of isolation, language difficulties, fragmented families and broader cultural or religious differences provided significant links.
Stage two was a mentor program, which furthered the developed the artistic skills of the students through a variety of cultural & arts mediums. These included workshops exploring Aboriginal dance; Japanese movement and theatre; contemporary and traditional music from a cross section of cultures; photojournalism and visual art mediums.
Stage three included a series of round table discussions and practical workshops uniting the stories of Stage One with the skills development of Stage Two. This enabled scripts & a musical score to be written for the final stage.
Stage four included performance rehearsals & backstage skills development which culminated in an experimental performance through multi-disciplined artforms in the round at The Capital Theatre on July 16 &17 1999.
Participating in this project were students & teachers from Bendigo Senior Secondary College with members of the stage design crew from Girton Grammar School and Catholic College. An original score of music was composed by local musicians and performed by the Bendigo Youth Orchestra. Financial partners were City of Greater Bendigo, Festivals Australia, The Myer Foundation & Victorian Multicultural Commission.
‘Roar culture’ was awarded the 1999 Local Government & the Arts Leadership Award for Best Practice Management of a Cultural Project

Lynda Newton
Project & Artistic Director

results.title: Woomera 2002
results.creator_credit: SKA TV, Tom McKendrick, Anthony Snowden and Laurel Heisman
results.brief_description: During Easter 2002, activists from around Australia converged upon Woomera Detention Centre to protest the federal government’s mandatory detention of refugees. Activists coordinated with the detainees’ protests within the detention centre, resulting in the mass breakout of 50 refugees. Most of the escapees were returned to the detention centre, but 11 detainees achieved freedom. The activists continued to protest the inhumane treatment of refugees in detention throughout the weekend, expressing their solidarity with both the detained refugees and also the people that escaped. This incident led to an increase in global awareness surrounding mandatory detention policies in Australia
results.creator_credit_for_label: SKA TV, Tom McKendrick, Anthony Snowden and Laurel Heisman

results.title: Short cuts. Magic movie screens: from vacuum cleaning to Plumper's dance party
results.creator_credit: Tina Douglas and Arts Project Australia
results.brief_description:
This is a compilation tape of animations produced by
disabled artists working with a mentor. “Short cuts”
features 30 seconds to 1 minute duration animation pieces and “Magic movie screens…” features slightly longer animated works of up to 5 minutes in length. The artists include Shirley Warke, Jimmy Fuller, Terry Williams,
Dorothy Berry, Cathy Staughton, Anne Lynch, John Northe, Fiona Longhurst, Alan Constable, Valerio Ciccone, Monica Burns, Tim Williams. Curated by Arts Project Australia with the support from Council of Adult, Community and Further Education, (Northern Metro Region).

results.title: Transit: SteamRail workshops
results.creator_credit: Northern Access TV, David McLauchlan and Michael Costello
results.brief_description:
This episode of ‘Transit’ is the ninth in a series of ten-quarter hour episodes produced by Northern Access Television in 1998.
‘Transit’ was a series of Community TV programs produced about Melbourne’s and Victoria’s Public Transport System and Transport Museum Groups by Michael Costello, a former Melbourne Tram Conductor. Other episodes included episodes on the Bendigo and Ballarat Tramway Museums, the Melbourne Transit Band, the Tramcar Restaurant and many others. In the 1998 series, various members of Northern Access TV assisted in the production of the programs. The programs were all made using volunteers from Northern Access TV on Mini DV cameras.
This episode looks at the SteamRail Workshops, located in the former Newport Railway Workshops. It consists of an interview where David McLauchlan interviews Keith Finlay, secretary of SteamRail Victoria Inc. This non-profit volunteer based association aims to preserve Victoria’s steam powered rail heritage and keep examples of them running for public tours to many destinations on Victoria’s Rail Network. In addition to preserving the days of steam-powered trains, the group also has sections that are dedicated to preserving Diesel and Electric rolling stock as well. During the interview, we see examples of the work undertaken on the carriages and associated equipment.

results.title: Kimberley country
results.brief_description:
Kimberley country music has its own unique style and is promoted each year through the Derby Country Music Festival where musicians from as far as Halls Creek, Fitzroy Crossing, Port Hedland and the desert area of the Kimberleys gather together and compete in the Festival Talent Quest. The Country Music Festival, through organisers such as Pam Masters (Festival Committee Member) and Cyril Archer (Festival Talent Quest
Co-ordinator), provides assistance and support to aspiring indigenous singers, songwriters and musicians. Geoffrey Fletcher, Kathleen Cox and Ashley Oobagooma talk about their background, their family and their passion for music as they each prepare for the journey to Derby and the Festival. The film concludes with performances by each of these three musicians at the Festival along with footage of the Benning Brothers, Fitzroy Express, Pigram Brothers, Gulingi Nunga, Kevin Gunn and Lucy Cox on stage. Beautifully photographed, particularly of the Australian landscape, and interesting and entertaining interviews along with some great country music.

results.title: Casterton lights up!
results.brief_description:
Casterton is a small rural town roughly half way between Melbourne and Adelaide, in far western Victoria. Like many smaller rural communities, Casterton has a rich agricultural history that claims not only to being the birthplace of the Kelpie but the first permanent inland Victorian settlement.
Due to a loss of both government and local industries during the nineties, Casterton found itself struggling to maintain its population. In April 1995, a public meeting was called to establish a survival plan. Attended by a hundred or so locals, the meeting produced a number of community initiatives including the developmentof a local phenomenon into a public festival.
In the eight years since, the annual Christmas lights festival has grown into the most important event on Casterton’s social calender. Today, two thirds of all homes in Casterton are lit each Christmas with up to 10,000 visitors passing through the town each December to take part in the nightly lights tours run by the local Lions Club
Casterton Lights Up! is an independently produced community documentary project written, directed, produced and funded by Melbourne Based filmmaker Glen Moore. The project was developed with the assistance and keen support of the Casterton community and aims to highlight the importance of community connectedness and spirit to the survival of small rural communities.

results.title: Police horses: who cares?
results.creator_credit: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters
results.brief_description:
Film opens with countryside shots at dawn and then goes into a fast-paced montage sequence of Police Horses in action with a funk soundtrack. Features footage of the horses in country, urban and city settings.

The work of a Victorian Department of Agriculture vet is then spotlighted as he tends to injured horses in the field and in a surgery/lab. Includes footage of a horse being X-Rayed who has an injured hoof.

Switches to the Victorian Police band in action and a their drum-carrying horse. Shots of kids enjoying the band play in an outdoor parade.

Then goes to show a Police Horse trainer at work at the Attwood Department of Agriculture stables. In the background of this training sequence planes from the nearby airport take-off and land in the background.

Similar training seqeunce takes place at the St Kilda Rd barracks with four horses being ridden. Up-beat synthesiser soundtrack. City-scape in the background, featuring the National Gallery of Victoria. This is followed by a more formal performance with full dress uniforms and big-band music. Horses and riders then escort the Queen as she travels in a car on parade down two city streets.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture, Reg Boulter and Vivian McWaters

Film opens with countryside shots at dawn and then goes into a fast-paced montage sequence of Police Horses in action with a funk soundtrack. Features footage of the horses in country, urban and city settings.

The work of a Victorian Department of Agriculture vet is then spotlighted as he tends to injured horses in the field and in a surgery/lab. Includes footage of a horse being X-Rayed who has an injured hoof.

Switches to the Victorian Police band in action and a their drum-carrying horse. Shots of kids enjoying the band play in an outdoor parade.

Then goes to show a Police Horse trainer at work at the Attwood Department of Agriculture stables. In the background of this training sequence planes from the nearby airport take-off and land in the background.

Similar training seqeunce takes place at the St Kilda Rd barracks with four horses being ridden. Up-beat synthesiser soundtrack. City-scape in the background, featuring the National Gallery of Victoria. This is followed by a more formal performance with full dress uniforms and big-band music. Horses and riders then escort the Queen as she travels in a car on parade down two city streets.

Switches to the Victorian Police band in action and a their drum-carrying horse. Shots of kids enjoying the band play in an outdoor parade.

Then goes to show a Police Horse trainer at work at the Attwood Department of Agriculture stables. In the background of this training sequence planes from the nearby airport take-off and land in the background.

Similar training seqeunce takes place at the St Kilda Rd barracks with four horses being ridden. Up-beat synthesiser soundtrack. City-scape in the background, featuring the National Gallery of Victoria. This is followed by a more formal performance with full dress uniforms and big-band music.
